item.title: Falluja’s Fall Stuns Marines Who Fought There
item.description: The bloody mission to wrest Falluja from insurgents in November 2004 meant more to the Marines than almost any other battle in the 12 years of war in Iraq and Afghanistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marines fighting insurgents in Falluja in 2004. The insurgents are back, and many Marines wonder if their sacrifice was in vain.

item.title: Santiago Journal: A Chilean Dictator’s Secret Book Collection: Heavy on Napoleon, Light on Fiction
item.description: General Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, known for his brutal 17-year rule, amassed about 50,000 volumes for his private library, using public money.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roberto Mardones of the President Pinochet Foundation, which got some of the leader’s books.

item.title: Syria Aid May Resume Despite Fears Over Where It Will Go
item.description: Officials insisted that no nonlethal supplies would be given directly to Syria’s Islamist groups, but questions remained over how to keep it from ending up in the wrong hands.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Damaged buildings line a street in the besieged city of Homs. American officials say restoring aid to Syria would send a message of support ahead of Jan. 22 talks.

item.title: Syrian Groups Try to Recruit U.S. Travelers
item.description: American intelligence and counterterrorism officials said Islamic extremist groups are trying to identify, recruit and train Westerners to carry out attacks when they return home.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Polio in Syria Is Said to Be Under Control
item.description: Confirmed cases have remained static for many weeks, an indication that vaccinations are having some effect.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Find Dead Tiger in S.U.V. in Wenzhou
item.description: The police report said the authorities suspected the carcass to be of a Siberian, or Amur, tiger, one of the world’s most endangered animals, and had sent samples to be tested.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: The police were surprised when they unwrapped the bound tarpaulin the men had been carrying.

item.title: Indian Diplomat Indicted in Employment Case
item.description: The federal indictment, returned in Manhattan, has the same charges as those in an earlier criminal complaint: visa fraud and making false statements.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: U.S. Mission in South Sudan Shows Limits of Military
item.description: Recent evacuation efforts highlight the remaining gaps in intelligence and communications that American forces face in Africa, commanders and independent analysts said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: The Lede: French Court Upholds Ban on Comedian Who Mocks Holocaust Commemoration
item.description: A French appeals court upheld a ban on performances by the stand-up comedian known as Dieudonné, who invented an obscene salute popular with anti-Semites.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Call to Honor Pakistani Boy in Fatal Tackle of a Bomber
item.description: Aitzaz Hasan, 15, stopped a suicide bomber whose target was believed to be a school in northwestern Pakistan, which has a history of sectarian violence.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Aitzaz Hasan, 15, stopped a suicide bomber whose target was believed to be a school.

item.title: With Release of Prisoners, Afghan Leader Again Defies U.S. Wishes
item.description: Intensifying his showdown with Washington, President Hamid Karzai ordered the release of 72 detainees, citing insufficient evidence.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: The prisoners to be released are being held at what used to be the main American prison near Bagram Air Field in Afghanistan.

item.title: French Far-Right Leader Aims for E.U. Parliament
item.description: Marine Le Pen, the leader of France’s National Front, laid out an ambitious plan to win seats this spring in the European Parliament, with the hope of provoking a “political crisis” there.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen took leadership of France's National Front in 2011 from her father, Jean-Marie Le Pen.

item.title: Japanese Begin to Question Protections Given to Homegrown Rice
item.description: A pending free trade agreement — and at least one Japanese farmer — are posing challenges to the elaborate system that protects the homegrown crop.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bags of hulled rice at Echigo Farm’s processing plant in Higashikanbara, Japan. Echigo Farm, which sells its organic rice at a premium, is a rare upstart in the Japanese rice business.

item.title: A Race for More Than the Mayor of Istanbul
item.description: As a corruption scandal has imperiled Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s hold on power, the spotlight is shifting to the race as the first step by opponents to challenge him at the ballot box.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Jodi Hilton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Suleymaniye Mosque in Istanbul. Houses in the area will be demolished as part of the governing party’s urban renewal project.

item.title: Even as Wages Rise, China Exports Grow
item.description: China’s export machine has continued to run even as blue-collar wages have soared between fivefold and ninefold in dollar terms in the last decade.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Timothy O'Rourke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Hong Kong Toys and Games Fair attracts exporters, whose sales are growing more slowly, but still growing.

item.title: New Estimate Sharply Raises Death Toll in South Sudan
item.description: The International Crisis Group said that the number of dead from the country’s conflict was close to 10,000 people, a major increase from earlier estimates by the United Nations.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Refugees in South Sudan on Thursday. The International Crisis Group said the conflict’s death toll was close to 10,000 people.

item.title: Tunisia’s Premier Resigns, Formally Ending His Party’s Rule
item.description: The resignation of Prime Minister Ali Larayedh was part of a carefully calibrated plan to end months of gridlock and prepare for new elections in the birthplace of the Arab Spring.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ali Larayedh of Tunisia submitted his resignation on Thursday.

item.title: European Central Bank Set to Do Whatever It Takes to Bolster Recovery
item.description: The European Central Bank’s president said he would “consider all available instruments” if the threat of deflation persists.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Germany to Help in Disposal of Syrian Chemical Weapons
item.description: The decision was in part to maintain international credibility in addressing Syria’s civil war, the foreign minister says.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: A training grenade was dismantled during a demonstration at a chemical weapons disposal facility near Münster in October.

item.title: Panel Recommends Transferring Yemeni From Guantánamo
item.description: A military panel has recommended transferring a Yemeni detainee in the first results of a long-delayed initiative to hold parole-like hearings at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Claims of Diplomats’ Mistreating Household Staff Are Far From the First
item.description: Although the arrest of an Indian diplomat has stirred strong reactions, there have been past criminal cases and lawsuits for similar allegations.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER and VIVIAN YEE
item.media:description: The Consulate General of India on the Upper East Side. Two domestic workers who sued Indian diplomats in New York claimed they had been forced to work extremely long hours for meager wages and subjected to threats and psychological coercion.

item.title: Bomber in Iraq Kills 22 Recruits Seeking to Fight Al Qaeda
item.description: The attacker infiltrated a line of men signing up to fight with government forces in Anbar Province.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Discovery of Bombs and Corpses Rattles Tense Caucasus Region
item.description: Improvised explosive devices and the bodies of six men who had been shot were found in the Stavropol area, stirring new worries about terrorism ahead of the Olympic Games planned for nearby Sochi.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: E.U. Panel Invites Snowden to Testify on Privacy Breaches
item.description: A parliamentary committee asked Edward J. Snowden to speak via video about protecting citizens’ privacy.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras/The Guardian, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The testimony would be done by video so Edward Snowden would not have to leave Russia.

item.title: As Iran Nuclear Talks Resume, Ayatollah Criticizes U.S.
item.description: The remarks by Ayatollah Khamenei may have been designed to strengthen Iran’s position at the negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and THOMAS ERDBRINK
